text: we're certainly here in a bill which is
of course the regional capital there's
been frankly euphoria I mean you could
barely move Kurdistan Regional flags in
the city centre last night there were
fireworks and dancing in the streets
further afield though things are much
more complicated and what we've had from
the international community are series
of statements overnight and in the last
couple of hours the United Nations
secretary-general Antonio Guterres has
expressed some concern over what's
taking place and said that he regretted
that the vote had been declared a
unilateral unilaterally without the
consent of the central government in
Bagdad and said that he took particular
note it the fact it had happened in
disputed areas that are under Peshmerga
Kurdish pesh MERGA control but are
disputed by Baghdad he pinpointed the
fact that the vote had taken place in
the city of Kirkuk which he said
suggested could be potentially
destabilizing now that echoes a message
that other countries have been saying
notably the us over night also talks
about its concerns about instability and
a distraction from the fight against
so-called Islamic state but
interestingly the Americans who of
course longtime allies of the Kurds also
said that the fact that those had taken
place would not change its historic
relationship with them on all those
Kurds who were celebrating late into the
night now they must now be full of
expectation what is it that they want to
happen now
well this is of course interesting point
about the political dynamics because the
president of the Kurdistan Region Masoud
Barzani had gone ahead with this vote
against much international pressure for
him not to do so so in doing that he has
raised the expectations of his people I
mean everybody you speak to here talked
about this being the fulfillment of a
dream of generations that they were able
to have this referendum vote but of
course it is non-binding and mr. Barzani
has said that he won't suddenly declare
independence there won't be a sudden
redrawing of international boundaries
unilaterally but he will proceed through
negotiations through democratic means I
think what it does is give him a greater
mandate in what is a complex political
economic and security relationship with
the central government within Baghdad
and of course with neighboring countries
